awd_titl_txt: RAISE: Design of co-assembling peptides as recombinant protein fusion tags for integrating enzymes  into supramolecular hydrogels
awd_abstract_narration:
This RAISE project is jointly funded by the Biological and Environmental Interactions of Nanoscale Materials program in CBET Division in the Engineering Directorate, the Molecular Biophysics Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences in the Biological Sciences Directorate, and the Office of Integrative Activities. 

In this multi-disciplinary project, nanomaterial scaffolds, or hydrogels, with immobilized enzymes will be produced using proteins as a design template. The proposed method provides a novel alternative to conventional immobilization techniques which are more difficult and time consuming.  This novel assembly technique is designed so that it selectively self-assembles into nano fiber structures. This targeted design and assembly of proteins into nanofibers is an exciting new research frontier that is largely unexplored with regard to both fundamental protein assembly and design of functional nanomaterials. A multi-disciplinary team of investigators will combine their expertise in modeling, imaging and characterization methods in order to demonstrate novel protein assembly and to advance fundamental understanding of protein assembly. The proposed technique will be an extraordinary improvement over the current state-of-the-art in protein assembly methods. Successful implementation of the proposed technique is anticipated to have a long-term broad impact on the engineering of novel functional materials for various biomedical and biotechnological applications. A variety of educational activities will be developed, including an iPad app on protein folding, and a video describing how computational methods can be used to design new biomaterials.

The proposed method bypasses conventional immobilization techniques in which the nanostructured scaffold is functionalized post-assembly via reactions at its surface. Instead, enzymes are expressed by bacteria from recombinant DNA with peptide fusion tags that mediate their assembly into nanostructured materials. The key to the method is the use of fusion tags that co-assemble into fibrillar structures when mixed with a complementary peptide, but remain unassembled when pure.  Co-assembling peptides are an exciting research frontier that is virtually unexplored in both protein biophysics and functional nanomaterials. The goals of the project are to demonstrate novel enzyme-functionalized supramolecular hydrogels, and to advance fundamental biophysical understanding necessary to predict peptide co-assembly.  Three specific aims are proposed: (1) characterize the assembly process and resultant structure for known â-sheet nanofiber-forming co-assembling peptide pairs, (2) design and test new pairs of selectively co-assembling peptides and, (3) test co-assembling peptides as tags to immobilize proteins in nanostructured biomaterials. Each aim will leverage the computational modeling expertise of PI Hall, with expertise in spectroscopic and microscopic characterization of peptide nanofibers provided by Co-PI Hudalla and solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance expertise provide by Co-PI Paravastu. The proposed enzyme immobilization method will be an extraordinary improvement over the current state-of-the-art in protein immobilization methods and hence opens the door to addressing long-standing challenges in installing biologically-active, folded proteins into biomaterials.  A variety of educational activities will be developed, including an iPad app on protein folding, and a video describing how computational methods can be used to design new biomaterials.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This RAISE project was jointly funded by the Environmental Engineering and Sustainability Nanoscale Interactions program in the CBET Division of the Engineering Directorate and the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division in the Biology Directorate. In this project, nanofiber-based scaffolds, or hydrogels, are produced through peptide design to place proteins and enzymes into specific 3-dimensional arrangements at the nano-scale.  The proposed method bypasses conventional immobilization techniques in which the nanostructured scaffold is functionalized post-assembly via reactions at its surface. The key to the new method is the use of fusion tags: co-assembling peptides that form fibrillar structures when mixed with a complementary peptide, but remain unassembled when pure.  Co-assembling peptides are an exciting research frontier that is virtually unexplored in both protein biophysics and functional nanomaterials. The goals of the project were to demonstrate novel enzyme-functionalized supramolecular hydrogels, and to advance the fundamental biophysical understanding necessary to predict peptide co-assembly.  Three specific aims were proposed: (1) characterize the assembly process and resultant structure for known β-sheet nanofiber-forming co-assembling peptide pairs, (2) design and test new pairs of selectively co-assembling peptides and, (3) test co-assembling peptides as tags to immobilize proteins in nanostructured biomaterials. The aims leveraged the computational modeling expertise of PI Hall with Co-PI Hudalla’s expertise in spectroscopic and microscopic characterization of peptide nanofibers and Co-PI Paravastu’s expertise in solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance. The proposed immobilization method is a significant improvement over the current state-of-the-art in protein immobilization methods and hence opens the door to addressing long-standing challenges in installing biologically-active folded proteins into biomaterials. 

Major research outcomes of the project include the following. The chemistry of the charged side-chains affects the types of hierarchical co-assembly structures that form at physiologic pH and ionic strength in water. The minimum charge per peptide needed to prevent the self-association of peptides was determined. However, charge-complementarity alone does not lead to a rigorous + - + - + - molecular arrangement, as one might expect. Instead, peptide co-assemblies demonstrate a fairly-high level of structural heterogeneity. A computational method for de novo design of co-assembling peptides was developed and validated via experiment. Such computational design methods are likely to help fix heterogeneities of molecular-level order in a way that heuristics alone cannot, paving the way to structurally refine supramolecular biomaterials. Peptides were designed to bind to the SARS-CoV-2 receptor binding domain; although they were unable to outcompete the ACE2:SARS-CoV-2 virus interaction, they could be used as detecting agents for diagnostic tools. Methods were found to direct peptide coassemblies to form nanoscale granular structures that are rapidly internalized by cells. This paves the way for application in a variety of biotechnological fields such as drug delivery, gene therapy, and in vitro cell engineering.  Experimental and computational efforts are under way to learn how temperature, peptide concentration and the presence of crowding agents such as polyethylene glycol  influence the final coassembled structures that form.  

Thus far the project has supported the education and professional training of 3 postdoctoral associates, 8 graduate students (4 are female), and 21 undergraduates (13 are female, 4 are underrepresented minorities).  Of the former postdoctoral associates, two have taken faculty positions and one works in industry. One former graduate student has taken a faculty position, another works in the pharmaceutical industry, and a third is now seeking a faculty position.  Thus far, 9 joint papers have been published; three more are in final stages of preparation. The PIs have each given major talks on this work at national and international meetings..

Major broader impact outcomes include the following. PI Hall continues her efforts to increase the number of women faculty in STEM departments in the US and to help them be successful.  She does this by meeting with women faculty at conferences, during seminar trips, and via individual interactions. PI Paravastu runs a program to promote undergraduate research by underrepresented minorities (URM) , and has large numbers of undergraduate researchers, both female and URM in his lab. (See data above.) Co-PI Hudalla hosts high school and undergraduate students in his lab, serves as chair of the University of Florida Biomedical Engineering (BME) Society Diversity Committee, and sits on the BME Council of Diversity.


Last Modified: 06/14/2024
Modified by: Carol K Hall
